intro: Petrophile fucifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaf rock-heath, is a flowering plant native to southeastern Australia. It belongs to the family Epacridaceae and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in open habitats such as heathlands and woodland edges. Its foliage consists of narrow, linear leaves that are often covered in a fine layer of white or pale hairs. Petrophile fucifolia is adapted to arid conditions and is often found in regions with low rainfall and well-drained soils.
